p: The proportion of females with a disseminated infection that had YFV-positive saliva (i.e., the transmission rate) was measured at 14 days post blood meal only for the highest infectious dose ( Fig 2). YFV was detected in the saliva of 33.3% (3/9) of Ae. malayensis females and 37.5% (3/8) of Ae. aegypti females, and the difference between the two species was not statistically significant ( p = 0.8576). Vector competence can be summarized by the overall proportion of blood-fed females that had YFV-positive saliva at 14 days post blood meal at the highest infectious dose (i.e., the transmission efficiency). Transmission efficiency was 11.5% (3/26) for Ae. malayensis and 14.3% (3/21) for Ae. aegypti ( Fig 2), and the difference between the two species was not statistically significant ( p = 0.7795).
